reasoning: The question targets a real fork in the paper’s argument: whether progress can route around compute bottlenecks via ‘strongest-link’ compute-light paths, which would materially affect SIE plausibility and the relative priority of compute governance vs monitoring other channels (high cruciality, strong decision hook). It is fairly anchored to this paper’s specific rebuttal (multi-route/strongest-link vs CES bottleneck), though similar questions could be asked in other AI-progress-bottleneck discussions (moderately high paper-specificity). It’s only moderately tractable because attributing ‘fraction of frontier-relevant progress’ across mechanisms is methodologically hard, partially proprietary, and sensitive to definitions; still, one could make progress via structured expert elicitation, bibliometrics, model release/postmortem analysis, and compute/ablation proxies. Clarity is decent but key terms (frontier-relevant, compute-light vs compute-heavy, what counts as ‘fraction’, and “increasing with automation”) remain ambiguous. Little dead weight: the branch point/indicators are mostly helpful scaffolding rather than fluff.
title: Compute-light versus compute-heavy routes to frontier progress
